newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian Rosneft oil firm mulls legal setback.
newsitem.headline: Russian Rosneft oil firm mulls legal setback.

text.p: Russian state-owned oil company Rosneft said on Monday it was mulling how to react to a court decision last week awarding one of Rosneft's prize assets to a rival oil firm.
A Moscow district court gave AO Purneftegaz to SIDANKO, in the latest twist to a long and bitter struggle for control of the key oil producer.
"We are considering the possibility of an appeal to the Supreme Arbitration Court," Rosneft spokesman Vladimir Tumarkin said, referring to the court decision.
The district court decided in favour of SIDANKO after SIDANKO had failed in two previous court attempts to wrest back control of the producer.

The ruling is the latest decision on the fate of Purneftegaz, whose ownership various Russian courts have awarded to SIDANKO and Rosneft. A 1994 government resolution gave Purneftegaz to SIDANKO but a later ruling shifted it back to Rosneft.
Purneftegaz would represent an important gain for SIDANKO and a key loss for Rosneft, the state oil holding company which is being privatised and which has few upstream assets.
Purneftegaz produced around eight million tonnes (160,000 barrels per day) in 1995, the last year for which figures were available.
Rosneft produced 13.10 million tonnes (262,000 bpd) of oil in 1996, including output from Purneftegaz. Its other leading oil production unit is Sakhalinmorneftegaz SKGZ.RTS.

Sibirsko-Dalnevostochnaya Neftyanaya Kompaniya (SIDANKO) produced 20.81 million tonnes (416,200 bpd) of oil in 1996. Its main production units include Chernogorneft CHGZ.RTS, Varyoganneftegaz VJGZ.RTS and Kondpetroleum COND.RTS.
